note.p: “If there be sprites in earth or air, / They surely have their dwelling there” (MS VIII)—The poem seems suggested by Manfred's invocation of the "Spirits of Earth and Air" in Byron's Manfred (I.i.41). The spirits' "dwelling there" in Ruskin's poem refers, probably, to the mountains, as in Manfred's call to "“Mysterious Agency! / Ye Spirits of the unbounded Universe! / Whom I have sought in darkness and in light-- / Ye, who do compass earth about, and dwell / In subtler essence--ye, to whom the tops / Of mountains inaccessible are haunts, / And Earth's and Ocean's caves familiar things--", although Byron's spirits haunt many places, "Earth--ocean--air--night--mountains--winds” (I.i.28-34, 132).

An association with Byron's play may have been suggested by the account of the poet's 1816 Continental journey, which traced a path similar to the Ruskins', and which Ruskin could have read in Thomas Moore's edition of the Letters and Journals of Lord Byron, which the family acquired in about December 1833, three months following their return home (Dearden, Library of John Ruskin, 231-32). In Moore's glossing of Byron's impressions of his Alpine journey with lines afterward composed for Manfred, he selects, however, only instances of the terrific and violent sublime, such as views of nature's ruin from the cliffs and glaciers of the Jungfrau (I.ii.66-69, 75-78, 85-87; II.iii.4-8) or of high cataracts in the valleys (II.i.1-8) (Moore, ed., Letters and Journals of Lord Byron, 2:232-34). Ruskin's tone seems amazed but serene and reverential.
